author: Michiel Van Roey
title: Control your data – privacy ledger
description: People can control (use of) their data via (legal) data rights. However, people don't know how to use/exercise them to their advantage

assessments.note: This project takes an existing centralised application and applies to in a decentralised way on the Cardano blockchain. This would drive a large number of users to interact repeated with the blockchain.

The proposal falls squarely within the Metadata Challenge in its emphasis on employing transaction metadata in a privacy-controlled fashion. It leverages an ongoing project by connecting it to Cardano metadata in a proof-of-concept application.

The proposal goes very well with the objectives of the challenge, as it aims to better educate and guide users about their legal rights with regard to metadata. This would be done from an app, which, as explained in the proposal, would follow several steps to demonstrate the content, approaching it through different aspects. Cardano would benefit because it would be used as a means of transactions; in this way, both the community and a problem involving metadata would benefit.

The proposers have the domain and technical experience to deliver this project and have detailed how they will do so. As it is expanding their current commercial product that would have a string incentive to deliver the project.

The proposal team's mature experience in this application area significantly mitigates project risk. The market-testing aspect of the plan will align the application for successful user adoption. The 12-month plan is somewhat vague as to specific activities in each of the three phases, but those are detailed elsewhere in the proposal.

The team that intends to develop the project is presented in a complete way. All members have an attached profile, where we can learn more about their professional trajectories. In addition, there are several attached media, which show us how the project is already structured and how the team has complete control over it. In this way, it is very safe how the project is in good hands to be carried out.

This is a well thought out and described project. It is a strong candidate to receive funding under this proposal. The proposer has also submitted another proposal for 42400 under the DApps and integrations challenge.

Although a great deal of specific information is provided in the proposal, much of that is background information about capabilities that the proposal would leverage. For the proposed proof of concept, quantifiable metrics for auditing progress and assessing successful completion are somewhat lacking.

There is a lot of information about what will be done, how it will be done, how much each step will cost and when it will be done. Everything is very well detailed, from the actions, to the parts that make up the project and the audience to be reached. I believe that the proposal is very complete in relation to its applicability, well-directed information and we can have a complete domain of how everything will happen.

solution: People use Profila's App to learn + exercise data rights; the privacy metadata ledger then provides legal proof = "unsubscribe on steroids"
experience: Privacy/Tech lawyer with 10Y XP in (project relevant) legal issues - consumer privacy; digital marketing; data rights & virtual currencies.
